did.head: Descriptive Summary

origination.label: Creator:
origination.corpname: University of Houston. Office of the President

did.abstract: The University of Houston was founded in 1927 as the Houston Junior College, operated by the Houston Independent School District. In 1934, the school was renamed the University of Houston and became a four-year college. The President's Office Records include correspondence, memoranda, publications, clippings, invitations, and related material dating from 1927-1981 that were received or created by the President of the University of Houston.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries

bioghist.head: Historical and Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The University of Houston was founded in 1927 as the Houston Junior College, operated by the Houston Independent School District. In 1934, the school was renamed the University of Houston and became a four-year college. In 1940, the first graduate degrees were awarded in the field of education. In 1945, the University became a separate, private entity with its own Board of Regents, chaired by Hugh Roy Cullen. Throughout this period E. E. Oberholtzer was the president of the University.

In 1950, W. W. Kemmerer became acting president of the University. Kemmerer served as president from 1952 to 1953, when C. F. McElhinney became acting president. General A. D. Bruce, who served as president until 1956 when he became chancellor of the University, followed him in 1954. Clanton W. Williams became president in 1956. In 1961, Philip G. Hoffman became president of the University of Houston. He held this position until 1977, when he became president of the UH System.

From 1924-1927 Oberholtzer served as Superintendent of the Houston Independent School District. With the formation of the Houston Junior College in 1927 he was named president. He remained president through the change from a two-year to a four-year institution in 1934 and continued until shortly before his death in 1950.

In 1929 Oberholtzer offered Kemmerer the position of Director of Curriculum and Research with Houston Independent School District. He remained in this position until June 1934, when he was appointed vice-president of the University of Houston. In October 1943, the position of "vice-president" was eliminated and Kemmerer's title was changed to Comptroller and Director of Curriculum. In spring 1944 Oberholtzer created the office and title "Assistant to the President" for Kemmerer. With Oberholtzer's retirement in 1950 Kemmerer became first acting president on June 1, 1950 and president on April 15, 1952. He was asked to resign on April 27, 1953.

Charles Flemming McElhinney (commonly known as C. F. McElhinney or "Mr. Mac") moved to Houston in 1934, taking the position of Assistant Director of Curriculum and Research for the Houston Independent School District from 1934-1939. He became Director of Research from 1939-1945, and business manager for the University of Houston which, until 1945, was operated by the Houston Independent School District. During this time he also served as a staff assistant to E. E. Oberholtzer. From 1945 until his retirement in 1973, McElhinney served as the business manager of the university. He also served as interim president of the University from 1953-1954, a position he agreed to serve in to allow time for the Board of Regents to select a new President.

General Andrew Davis (A.D.) Bruce was the third president and the first chancellor of the University of Houston. Bruce became president of the university on September 1, 1954 and chancellor in December 1956. He retired from the university after the 1960-61 academic year. In 1957 Bruce organized a Board of Governors, composed of the regents of the university and prominent Houstonians. In November 1959 the governing board sought state support for the University, which had grown rapidly in the preceding years. Bruce was one of the first to advocate tax support for the University of Houston.

Clanton Ware Williams served as the fourth president of the University of Houston from 1956-1960. Williams joined the University of Houston as Vice-President for Academic Affairs in January 1955. He was named president of the University at the December 10, 1956 meeting of the Board of Regents. At this same meeting, A.D. Bruce was named chancellor and chief executive officer of the university. With this new reporting structure, the president was entrusted with the internal affairs while the chancellor was charged with both external relationships and overall responsibility. From August 11, 1960 to September 1, 1961, Williams retained the title of president, but was on a leave of absence.

In 1957 Philip Guthrie Hoffman came to the University of Houston as Vice President and Dean of Faculties. He was appointed as the fifth president of the University of Houston in September 1961, and was officially inaugurated on April 27, 1962. Hoffman served as president until 1977, when he became president of the University of Houston System. He remained in this position until his retirement in 1979. Some of the advances made during Hoffman's tenure include reorganization and augmentation of administrative staff, including shifts within the ranks of the academic deans; conducting an institution-wide self-study; completing a new master plan for campus development; and taking first steps toward the formation of a University of Houston System.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In 1985 the President's Office transferred custody of most of its historic files to the Archives. At the time of transfer, the collection was referred to as the University of Houston Presidential Papers prior to 1979 and it consisted of forty-two boxes divided into three series. The first series of twenty-one boxes was processed in 1997 as the Presidents' Records 1927-1979. The other two series from this transfer were initially processed in 2001 as the Philip G. Hoffman Papers.

It was decided in 2002 that, while the processing of the University of Houston Presidential Papers Prior to 1979 as two separate collections was acceptable; it was not ideal for research purposes. To improve the accessibility to the collections it was determined that the Philip G. Hoffman Papers and the Presidents' Records should be combined back into one collection, the President's Office Records. As the bulk of the material within President's Records seemed to correspond most directly to the first series (Subject Files) within the Hoffman Papers that is where the majority of re-filing and integration was needed.

The President's Office Records include correspondence, memoranda, publications, clippings, invitations, and related material dating from 1927-1981 that were received or created by the President of the University of Houston. The bulk of the material dates from the mid-1960s to 1978 and was generated during the presidency of Philip G. Hoffman.

The files are rich in materials documenting the history of state support for the University, which was received in 1963, as well as materials showing the rise of student discontent on campus in the late 1960s and early 1970s. See particular student groups such as AABL (Afro-Americans for Black Liberation) for information about the group and its activities and the administration's reaction and response to their demands. This collection also documents the early history of the University of Houston System, with its campuses in Clear Lake, Victoria, and at UH-Downtown. There is also a substantial amount of material relating to the investment scandal of the late 1970s and to the self-study that was undertaken in the mid 1970s.

Photographs in the collection have been transferred to the UH Historical Photographs Collection in the University Archives. A separation sheet notes their original location in the collection and provides a brief description of the items. All student transcripts in the collection have been removed and destroyed, following the Texas Open Records Act. For similar reasons, all materials relating to search committees and personnel decisions have been removed from the collection and are closed to the public.

The collection is arranged into series and sub-series based primarily on how it was originally received in 1985. The nine series are Subject Files, Mission Self-Study, Coordinating Board, President's Cabinet, Investment Investigation, Council of Presidents, Speeches/Oral Interview/Biographical Information, Business/Personal, and President's Christmas Cards. For preservation and access reasons the collection has been re-boxed and re-foldered. New folder titles conform, as closely as possible, to original folder titles, except when the original was obviously incomplete, incorrect, or confusing. Original folder and item order has been maintained whenever possible. Exceptions were made when folders were obviously misfiled or when no order was apparent.
An index to the collection is available. Please contact Special Collections for more information.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The material in this collection is in the public domain. However, Special Collections owns the physical items in our collections, and all reproduction restrictions apply.

controlaccess.head: Index Terms
controlaccess.p: Terms are either Library of Congress Subject Headings or taken from local sources.

scopecontent.p: This series is the largest in the collection containing forty-nine boxes of general working files that are presumed to be the President's office files. Materials date from 1927 to 1980, with the bulk of the materials dating between 1960 and 1978. The files cover almost every aspect of the University including student groups, commencement, committees, accreditation, the different colleges, national education related organizations and associations, and the other campuses within the University of Houston System. Files in this series have been arranged alphabetically and then chronologically when necessary.

scopecontent.p: This series contains twenty-seven folders that relate to the University's Mission Self-Study. President Hoffman and Vice President Emmett Fields announced the Mission Self-Study at the General Faculty Meeting on January 11, 1974. The purpose of the study was to fulfill a requirement by the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools that each member institution conduct a self-study at least once each decade for re-accreditation purposes. The materials date from 1974 to 1976 and include extensive data used in the study and the results from the study itself. The original folder order was chronological and has been maintained except where folders were obviously misfiled.

scopecontent.p: This series contains eighty-five folders that relate to the Higher Education Coordinating Board. The Higher Education Coordinating Act of 1965 provided that the Coordinating Board shall "review periodically all degree and certificate programs offered by institutions of higher education." (Section 10, Paragraph [5]). The materials in this series are extensive in nature consisting primarily of meeting minutes and date from 1968-1976. The series is divided into two sub-series, Active and Inactive, based on the order received.

did.unittitle: Dr. Bevington Reed Commissioner of Higher Education, 1968-1969
Dr. Bevington Reed Commissioner of Higher Education, 1969-1971
Dr. Bevington Reed Commissioner of Higher Education, 1972-1975

scopecontent.p: This series contains twenty-five folders that relate to meetings of the President's Cabinet. These materials are extensive in nature and include agendas and minutes for most of the President's Cabinet meetings from September 1977 through October 1979. The Cabinet met generally on a monthly basis to discuss significant issues facing the University. These issues included, but were not limited to, the financial affairs of the university, search processes for senior level management positions, building expansions, and major renovations.

This series containing 126 folders covers almost every aspect of the largest scandal in the history of the University of Houston, which involved short-term investments made on behalf of the university resulting in the loss of several millions of dollars. The materials date from 1970 to 1981, with the majority dating between the years of 1976 and 1978. The files in this series are presumed to be the President's office files and they consist of a variety of materials including reports, correspondence, financial documents, affidavits, and news clippings. This series has been divided into two sub-series based on how it arrived at the Archives. The two sub-series are General and Vice President Singleton's In-house Investigation. The materials within the sub-series were in no order so the Archivist has imposed one. All oversized materials have been boxed separately and are found at the end of this series.
The items in this sub-series date from 1975-1981 and the folders have been arranged in roughly chronological order.

scopecontent.p: President Hoffman and the Board of Regents charged Vice President Roger Singleton to analyze the activities that had led to the Board of Regent's investigation into the university's investment fund activity. This sub-series consists primarily of working files and correspondence that he used during his investigation. The materials in this series include correspondence amongst the parties involved, copies of ledger entries and financial transactions, and other relevant materials. This sub-series has been divided into five sub-sub-series: Roger Singleton; Douglas G. MacLean; Correspondence; Financial, Banking, and Legal Materials; and General Research and Reference Materials.

The university hired Roger Singleton in 1969 as assistant dean and assistant professor of accounting in the College of Business Administration. Later he served as Vice President and Dean of Faculties on an interim basis and as Executive Vice President of the University of Houston System. This sub-sub-series relates directly to Singleton himself and is arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Recap of Events Pertaining to Short-term Investment Investigation, 1977-1978

scopecontent.p: When Charles F. McElhinney retired in 1973, Douglas G. MacLean replaced him as the University's top financial officer. During MacLean's tenure, Sam Harwell, J. Treadway Brogdon, and Harold W. Scott all answered to him. After the improper activity was uncovered, MacLean was placed on a six-month administrative leave with pay. When the UH regents announced their findings regarding the investigation, one of their recommendations was that MacLean not be kept on staff when his leave of absence expired. The others who had been responsible for supervising Harwell's investment program either resigned or retired. This sub-sub-series relates directly to Douglas MacLean and the folders are arranged chronologically.

This sub-sub-series consists primarily of correspondence with various entities including, but not limited to, financial institutions, banks, law firms, and various university departments. Folders are arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: University Officials, Minimum Reserve Requirements (Banking Institutions), Proposed Air Travel Procedures, Minor Capital Improvement Program, 1974
Correspondence and Financial Transactions with Financial Institutions, 1974-1976

scopecontent.p: This sub-sub-series consists of extensive financial records and reports relating to the university's short-term investments. Of special interest are Brogdam's Report on Short-term Investments and Hoffman's testimony before the House of Representatives Committee on Cash Management. Folders are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: This series contains ten folders that date from 1965-1978. The Council of Presidents was a group of Presidents from the Public Senior Colleges and Universities in the State of Texas. This group examined various issues related to higher education including continuing education, pay raises for state employees, medical and health fees, and many other issues.
This series dates from 1962 to 1976 and contains materials relating to trips Hoffman took and the automobile he used while in his position at UH.

did.unittitle: Trip-Hawaiian Carnival Summer Alumni Federation, Summer 1966

scopecontent.p: This series consists of fifteen folders dating from 1961 to 1977. It contains samples of the Christmas Cards sent out by the President's Office during Philip Hoffman's term as president.
